children: The key to using exogeneous input signals is the same as in the rest of the SciML universe: just use the function in the definition of the differential equation. For example, if it's a standard differential equation, you can use the form
is an exogenous input signal into
. Another form that could be useful is a closure. For example:
which encloses an extra argument into
is now the interface-compliant differential equation definition.
Note that you can also learn what the exogenous equation is from data. For an example on how to do this, you can use the [Optimal Control Example](
optcontrol) which shows how to parameterize a
by a universal function and learn that from data.
Example of a Neural ODE with Exogenous Input
In the following example, a discrete exogenous input signal
is defined and used as an input into the neural network of a neural ODE system.
